Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impacts of Prior Work Experience on Adult, Non-traditional, Engineering Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to create new pathways for non-traditional engineering students by examining the role of prior work experiences, identity, and expertise. By applying the theoretical framework of multiple identities, this work collects and analyzes qualitative and quantitative data from traditional and non-traditional engineering undergraduate students at three diverse institutes of higher education: a large public university (U. C. Berkeley), a small private university (University of New Haven), and a community college (Ca√±ada College). The primary research question being addressed is: How does prior engineering-related work experience impact engineering student identity and approach to engineering study? This is investigated through a systematic mixed-methods approach combining semi-structured interviews, think-aloud protocols, surveys, and the collection of persistence data.

The study provides critical insights to enable engineering educators to be more effective in their educational efforts, and makes substantial contributions to our understanding of engineering identities and understanding of students' abilities and thinking processes. By filling gaps in current understanding of the identities, level of expertise, and experiences of these students, the study aims to improve persistence outcomes for engineering students and increase the number of qualified engineering graduates. The results help build and diversify STEM education by reaching out to and increasing the retention of older students which include females and underrepresented minorities. The partnership between the small private university, the large state institution, and the community college maximize opportunities for widespread integration and dissemination of findings, and strengthen pathways for non-traditional students. This work supports efforts to expose all engineering students to obtain work experience/internships and help encourage the current workforce to pursue a degree. The PIs plan to offer several regional workshops and webinars to broadly disseminate the findings and make the data collected easily available to academic advisors, especially at community colleges or those working with transfer students; veterans' affairs groups, college admissions, enrollment management, and recruiting officers; engineering faculty and administration; and engineering student leaders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work gives insights into the diversity of student perspectives in engineering programs, and different ways that students may engage with one another and with faculty.

Undergraduate engineering students aged 25 and over are an important but sometimes overlooked component of engineering classrooms. Adult students have a variety of backgrounds, experiences, and pathways that inform their engagement with engineering learning and their relationships with their peers. Many adult and nontraditional students have work experience in an engineering environment, and bring knowledge of practical applications as well as leadership and teamwork skills to their engineering study.  Our work showed that experienced adult students in engineering have complex relationships with their traditional-aged peers, approach student-faculty interactions differently from younger peers, and bring their maturity and connectedness to life experience and the workplace to their engineering and design coursework. Our research drew from adult engineering students in a range of institutional environments, including community college, and public and private universities.

We found that adult students did largely identify as others within their academic community. Analysis of the interviews led to the identification of several key categories that created divide within the groups, including age, priorities, and maturity. Age was the topic most often brought up, but more personal differences between themselves and the peers, including their additional responsibilities to their families and their more mature interests, contributed greatly to their co-construction of an identity as a person who is not the norm, someone who does not quite fit in.

Adult students described instances in which they felt ignored, left out, or singled out because of their age.

We identified three major themes linked to feeling disconnected from their peers: focus, experience, and competition. Adults spoke at length about each of these areas, providing detailed insight into how they viewed their peers. As others in their environment, adult students tend to form their identities through oppositional judgements of their peers. Ever striving to be successful students they highly value their own dedication, self-motivation, and commitment to active learning. They describe most younger students as lacking these qualities, as unfocused students “meandering” through school.

We also found differences between adult students and traditional-age students in their interactions with faculty. Focusing on students in the same department at the large public research institute, we found that the traditional age students are very likely to cite feelings of intimidation or embarrassment that interfere with their ability to develop relationships or learn from faculty members. Adult students provided a very different perspective on this. They do see that their younger peers are intimidated by faculty and even graduate students, but they are not intimidated or embarrassed themselves. They noted that faculty members are just people doing their jobs; they are people who want to help students learn. Adult students also said that they are “too old” to be embarrassed about asking a question. Their maturity and self-confidence when approaching faculty members is potentially an area where researchers and faculty can work to develop this approach among traditional age students.

We were able to identify several areas in which adult students were successful at connecting with their peers which lay the groundwork for forming positive relationships and socially integrating. Our work  highlighted three sources of connection: shared engineering student identity, admiration for inspiring young students, and the formation of quasi-mentorship-mentee relationships between students. Adult students at a very basic level described fondness for their fellow students because of their shared the engineering student identity. Adult students were quick to connect with serious students who, like them, valued dedication, academic engagement, and persistence. This subset of students was often described as inspiring and relationships with these students positively impacted adult learners academic experience. We identified key ways for adult students with experience to feel validated and included, primarily through sharing their experiences and giving advice to their peers. Many adult students truly want to better themselves and also offer help to others; institutions of higher education should be quick to allow them the platform to do so.

Results of design data showed the adult student design process data that we collected is largely within the range of prior reported outcomes for other groups. Further analysis may highlight aspects of their process that are more similar to either traditional student or professional groups.

Long term, this project is likely to make a significant impact on the recruitment, support, and retention of non-traditional and adult students in engineering. By better understanding the educational experience of adult engineering students, we can all positively impact practices in engineering education to support and engage this important minority group.
